# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String; text_width::Int = 10)
    lines = []
    for word in split(text, " ")
        # Calculate the length of the current line with the new word
        current_line_length = sum([length(w) for w in lines]) + length(word)
        if current_line_length <= text_width
            # Append the word to the current line
            push!(lines, word)
        else
            # If the line is too long, start a new line and add the word
            push!(lines, "")
            while true # Infinite loop for brevity, replace with actual condition
                if length(word) <= text_width
                    # Append the word to the new line
                    push!(lines, word)
                    break
                else
                    # If the word is longer than the width, remove the first character and continue
                    word = strip_first_char(word)
                end
            end
        end
    end
    return join(lines, "\n")
end

function strip_first_char(s::String)
    return s[2:end]
end

# Example usage
wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines") # Should return something like "This function will\nwrap words into lines"
```

Please note that the `strip_first_char` function is used to handle the case where a word is longer than the maximum line width. This function removes the first character of the word and continues until either the word is shorter than the width or there's no more word left to process. The actual implementation of this function could be improved by taking into account edge cases such as empty lines or very long words that never fit within the specified width.
